expanded_description: Section 1.4 covers systems of linear equations and inequalities - solving problems with multiple conditions simultaneously. Students will learn to solve 2x2 systems using three methods: graphing (finding intersection points), substitution (replacing one variable with an equivalent expression), and elimination (adding equations to cancel variables). The section also covers systems of inequalities, where the solution is the overlapping shaded region. These techniques are essential for real-world problems with multiple constraints, such as break-even analysis, mixture problems, and optimization.

core_concept.principle:
**Systems of Linear Equations**: Two or more linear equations with the same variables. The solution is the point(s) that satisfy all equations simultaneously.

**Solution Methods**:
• **Graphing**: Graph both lines; intersection point is solution
• **Substitution**: Solve one equation for a variable, substitute into the other
• **Elimination**: Add or subtract equations to eliminate a variable

**Types of Solutions**:
• **One solution**: Lines intersect at one point (consistent, independent)
• **No solution**: Parallel lines (inconsistent)
• **Infinite solutions**: Same line (consistent, dependent)

**Systems of Inequalities**: Solution is the overlapping region where all inequalities are true
core_concept.explanation: Think of a system of equations as solving a mystery where two different clues must both be true. Where the clues intersect is your answer! For example, "the sum of two numbers is 10" and "their difference is 4" - only one pair works (7 and 3). For inequalities, imagine overlapping colored regions on a map - the solution is where all colors overlap, like finding a location that satisfies multiple conditions at once (within budget, within time, etc.).

sections.section_title: 1.4 Systems of Linear Equations and Inequalities
sections.introduction: Systems of equations allow us to find where multiple conditions are satisfied simultaneously. This is essential for solving problems with multiple constraints, from business decisions (when does revenue equal cost?) to science (where do two moving objects meet?) to everyday situations (which phone plan is cheaper for my usage?).

introduction_image.caption: Figure 1.4.2: A system of equations finds the point that satisfies all equations.

key_concept.definition:
A **system of linear equations** consists of two or more linear equations with the same variables. For a 2x2 system (two equations, two variables), the solution is an ordered pair $(x, y)$ that makes both equations true.

**Three Possible Outcomes:**
1. **One solution**: Lines intersect at exactly one point (different slopes)
2. **No solution**: Lines are parallel (same slope, different y-intercepts)
3. **Infinite solutions**: Lines are the same (same slope AND same y-intercept)

**Methods for Solving:**
• **Graphing**: Plot both lines, read intersection point
• **Substitution**: Solve one equation for a variable, substitute into the other
• **Elimination**: Multiply equations to match coefficients, then add/subtract to eliminate a variable

**Systems of Inequalities:**
• Graph each inequality separately
• The solution is the region where all shaded areas overlap
• Boundary lines follow same solid/dashed rules as single inequalities
key_concept.context: Systems model real situations with multiple conditions: finding the break-even point (cost = revenue), mixing solutions (acid concentration problems), comparing phone plans (when is Plan A cheaper than Plan B?), determining loads (weight and volume constraints), and solving puzzles with two unknown numbers.

worked_examples.title: Graphing a System of Inequalities
worked_examples.problem: Graph the solution region for: $\begin{cases} y \le 2x + 1 \\ y > -x + 3 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation:
Boundary: $y = 2x + 1$ (solid line)
Y-intercept: $(0, 1)$, slope 2: up 2, right 1 → $(1, 3)$
Test $(0, 0)$: $0 \le 1$ ✓ True
Shade **below** the line

Boundary: $y = -x + 3$ (dashed line)
Y-intercept: $(0, 3)$, slope -1: down 1, right 1 → $(1, 2)$
Test $(0, 0)$: $0 > 3$ ✗ False
Shade **above** the line (opposite side from origin)

step_by_step.explanation: Solution is where both shadings overlap
step_by_step.calculation: Look for region that is below first line AND above second line

step_by_step.explanation: Find where boundaries meet (optional, for reference)

worked_examples.final_answer: The solution is the region below the solid line $y = 2x + 1$ and above the dashed line $y = -x + 3$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: For systems of inequalities, graph each separately and find the intersection of the shaded regions.

worked_examples.title: Real-World System of Inequalities
worked_examples.problem: You're making small (x) and large (y) crafts to sell. Each small craft takes 2 hours and uses $10 in materials. Each large craft takes 3 hours and uses $15 in materials. You have at most 30 hours available and at most $120 to spend. Write and graph the system of inequalities representing possible numbers of crafts.

step_by_step.explanation: $x$ = number of small crafts, $y$ = number of large crafts

step_by_step.calculation:
Boundary: $2x + 3y = 30$
X-intercept: $(15, 0)$
Y-intercept: $(0, 10)$
Test $(0, 0)$: $0 \le 30$ ✓ True
Shade below/left of solid line

Boundary: $10x + 15y = 120$
Divide by 5: $2x + 3y = 24$
X-intercept: $(12, 0)$
Y-intercept: $(0, 8)$
Test $(0, 0)$: $0 \le 120$ ✓ True
Shade below/left of solid line
Solution is in first quadrant where both shaded regions overlap

worked_examples.final_answer:
System: $\begin{cases} x \ge 0 \\ y \ge 0 \\ 2x + 3y \le 30 \\ 10x + 15y \le 120 \end{cases}$
The solution region is the polygon in the first quadrant below both lines.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world problems often include multiple constraints and non-negativity conditions. The solution region represents all feasible combinations.

summary: Section 1.4 covers systems of linear equations and inequalities. For 2x2 systems, three methods are available: graphing (visual, good for estimation), substitution (isolate and replace), and elimination (add/subtract to cancel variables). Systems can have one solution (intersecting lines), no solution (parallel lines), or infinite solutions (same line). For systems of inequalities, graph each inequality separately, then identify the overlapping region where all conditions are satisfied. Real-world applications include break-even analysis, mixture problems, and optimization under multiple constraints. These skills are essential for understanding relationships between multiple conditions and for preparing for linear programming and more advanced applications in later mathematics courses.
